title: Reverting Commits ‚Ü©Ô∏è
ques:
You made a mistake in the last commit `abc1234` and pushed it. You need to undo the changes by creating a **new commit** that reverses the effect of the bad commit.

Revert the commit `abc1234`.
explanation: **`git revert`** creates a *new* commit that is the exact opposite of the specified commit, making it safe for shared history.

title: Soft Reset üç¶
ques:
You want to undo your last commit but **keep** your changes in the staging area to fix them.

Perform a **soft reset** to the previous commit (`HEAD~1`).
explanation: **`git reset --soft`** moves the HEAD pointer back but leaves your index (staging area) and working directory unchanged.

title: Hard Reset üî®
ques:
You want to completely discard all local changes and commits, resetting your branch to match `origin/main` exactly.

Perform a **hard reset**.
explanation: **`git reset --hard`** resets the index and working tree. Any changes to tracked files in the working tree since `<commit>` are discarded.

title: Adding Submodules üß©
ques:
You want to include another Git repository as a subdirectory in your project.

Add the repository `https://github.com/lib/lib.git` as a submodule in the folder `libs/my-lib`.
explanation: **`git submodule add`** clones an external repository into a specific path and adds it to the `.gitmodules` file.

title: Git Flow Initialization üåä
ques: Which command initializes a repository to use the **Gitflow** branching model with default branch names?
explanation: **`git flow init`** sets up the configuration for the git-flow branching model, asking for branch naming conventions.
